active_learning.discussion_prompt: Debate the trade-offs of centralizing vs. decentralizing emergency contact management in an Emergency Services Sector (ESS) organization during a cyber incident. Consider factors like accessibility, security, update frequency, and compliance with NIST SP 800-61.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

layer.name: Layer 1
layer.content: Core definitions: Emergency contact information (names, roles, phones, emails); Emergency Services Sector (ESS: law enforcement, fire, EMS, 911); Cybersecurity incident (violation of security policies). Importance in rapid communication during incidents.

layer.name: Layer 2
layer.content: Industry standards: NIST Cybersecurity Framework ('Respond' function: Response Planning, Communications); NIST SP 800-61 (incident handling with communication strategies); CISA guidelines for critical infrastructure. Structure: Centralized vs. decentralized repositories.

layer.name: Layer 3
layer.content: Best practices (sourced from NIST/CISA): 1) Maintain centralized, encrypted, access-controlled repository; 2) Conduct quarterly audits and updates; 3) Integrate with IR plans; 4) Test via tabletop exercises and drills; 5) Restrict access via role-based controls; 6) Secure against unauthorized access (e.g., multi-factor authentication).

layer.name: Layer 4
layer.content: Link to IR, BC/DR plans; Optimization for ESS (e.g., redundancy for outages); Compliance auditing; Advanced scenarios like hybrid threats. Create scalable plans with automation (e.g., HR-integrated updates).
